Award.AbstractNarration:
1548901
Kakuturu

This project proposes to explore an innovative use of x-ray micro computed tomography to investigate the effect of deicing salt on stormwater filter media. Stormwater filters are critical in preventing floods and protecting the environment by allowing stormwater to infiltrate to ground and entrapping the pollutants. Prior studies have raised concerns about the deicing salts' role in deterioration of stormwater filter media and environmental contamination. This project outlines a plan to conduct flow tests, using NaCl as a deicing salt, and to evaluate the pre- and post-salt-application pore structures' in stormwater filter media using x-ray micro computed tomography.

This project will explore x-ray micro computed tomography to examine stormwater filter media pore structure. The data will be analyzed using computer simulations for developing an understanding of deterioration, a critical research need. Two hypotheses are to be tested: (1) There is a statistical correlation between "flow rate" and "ratio of active porosity to total porosity." (2) Given that the total amount of NaCl is similar, differences in stormwater filter media degradation (the ratio of "active porosity" to "total porosity") will not be significantly different at three different NaCl concentrations. The results of this research will address two scientific questions: (1) How does the pore structure of a SFM change due to application of NaCl? (2) Is there a relationship between the "ratio of active porosity to total porosity" and infiltration rate? This project's goal is to explore and test this radically different research approach for addressing the critical need to scientifically understand the deterioration of stormwater filter media. The PI proposes to achieve this goal by using state-of-the-art of x-ray micro computed tomography, and a combination of discrete element and lattice Boltzmann methods simulations. This approach has demonstrated success in other research fields, for example, medicine, biology, agriculture, geology, industrial, etc. The PI has successfully conducted a pilot study using x-ray micro computed tomography for visualization of SFMs' pore structure. The same samples will be scanned before and after salt application. The three dimensional image data will be used for constructing three dimensional pore structures of stormwater filter media. The three dimensional pore spaces will be used in morphological analysis and model simulations. Results (distribution of porosity, gradients, etc.) will help us in understanding the mechanism of SFM deterioration. This project will establish x-ray micro computed tomography as a suitable method for studying porous media, and will transform the scientific understanding of different porous media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report:

Deterioration of Stormwater Filter Media by Deicing Salts: X-ray Micro Computed Tomography (µCT)

 Have you ever applied deicing salts (snow melt) on your driveway, sidewalk, and entrance, just to make sure no one skids? Have you seen maintenance crews applying them on roads? Do you know deicing salts adversely affect our waterbodies and environment? Snow eventually melts and flows down carrying deicing salts. Stormwater infiltration into ground is important to ensure water supplies later on. Otherwise, more stormwater quickly runs into streams and could cause flooding! Stormwater ponds, swales, etc. are built to increase infiltration and to filter-out pollutants, which otherwise could spread!

 Deicing salts are typically NaCl that release sodium and chloride ions, which could change the internal structure of soils. They could clog soils and reduce their infiltration and pollutant-entrapment capacities. Scientists have not yet understood the mechanism through which deicing salts affect soils, because no one measured the changes NaCl makes inside soils! The intellectual merit of this project is that it innovatively applied the x-ray micro-computed-tomography (µCT) to visualize the samples’ interiors, and developed image-based techniques.  

 This NSF-funded EAGER (EArly-concept Grants for Exploratory Research) project investigated the effects of NaCl on three soils by conducting (a) flow tests that simulated stormwater infiltration, (b) innovative application of x-ray µCT, and (c) innovative image-processing and computer-simulation techniques to understand the mechanisms involved. The goal of this research is to explore the viability of these innovative µCT and analytical techniques. MicroCT is based on the differences between x-ray absorption of different materials (example: soil particles and air) and enables us to visualize the samples’ interiors.

 Fig. 1 is the µCT schematic, showing a cylindrical sample securely taped on the computer-controlled swivel base. Imaging was done by focusing x-rays on the perpendicularly-oriented vertical-plane through the sample’s centre. The sample was rotated through a small angle after each imaging step. The rotation angle and size of x-ray focal-spot was regulated to give the image resolution required. User-fees were paid to scan samples using a Bruker’s SkyScan 1173.

Initially, we tested eighteen silty-sand samples (20-mm dia. x 27-mm long) scanning them at 15-µm (0.015-mm = 0.000591-inch) resolution. It was chosen to capture the smallest pore expected, because (a) the smallest particle used was about 45-µm, and (b) the corresponding smallest pore was expected be 1/3 of 45-µm.

Finally, we tested six sand samples (30-mm dia. x 53-mm long) scanning them at 53-µm resolution. It was chosen based on the smallest particle used was about 150-µm. Samples were scanned before and after the flow tests, same way!

 Fig. 2 shows the schematic of flow tests conducted maintaining a constant-head difference (varied for tests). Per the Darcy’s law, flow rate is proportional to hydraulic gradient (i), the ratio of constant-head difference to sample length.

Initially, nine samples were tested at three different i-ratios (triplicates) using salt-free water, and other nine samples were tested at three different i-ratios (triplicates) using water @ 150 mg/l NaCl. Finally, six sand samples were tested at four different higher i ratios (two singles and two duplicates) using salt-free water. The goal of experimental design was to investigate the effects of NaCl, i-ratio, and particle size.

Fig. 3 presents a picture of flow test running on triplicates (C23, C26, and C31). The three flow cells were fed by a single supply tank, in which a constant water level was maintained by allowing overflow and continuously topping it up with supply from a balancing tank. Fig. 4 shows the results of flow test on triplicates C17, C18, C21.

Comprehensive image analysis is required to understand the mechanism through which deicing salts affect soils:

(a) The images were first analyzed using Bruker’s CTAn software that gave the pore-size-distribution of samples, slice-wise (15-µm or 53-µm) porosity, besides other morphological parameters. The slice-wise porosity was used to plot the flow-induced changes in the vertical direction; Fig. 5 for sample C17.

(b) Later, the images were analyzed with Avizo-Fire software to obtain discernible 3D individual objects, with a goal of using them as representations of actual particles. The sizes and 3D positions of these objects can be used in computer simulations based on coupled DEM-CFD (discrete-element-method + computational-fluid-dynamics) models. Fig. 6 shows the individual objects imported into Itasca’s Particle Flow Code (PFC) to run coupled DEM-CFD simulations. Understanding gained from these ongoing simulations will reveal the mechanism of deicing salts on soils.

Broader impacts of this project included the mentoring of one graduate student and two undergraduate students (both women engineers) through lab and computer experiences. The results are shared with public via Scholar-Sphere. The dissemination of results was done as one podium presentation at a national conference in California, and as a poster at an international conference in Sweden. The results are being prepared for publication as journal papers.
